thread.title: Rosenberg: Online fantasy sports should be regulated, taxed
thread.title_full: Rosenberg: Online fantasy sports should be regulated, taxed | Boston Herald

author: Matt Stout
title: Rosenberg: Online fantasy sports should be regulated, taxed
text:
Senate President Stanley Rosenberg said the exploding fantasy sports market needs to be regulated and taxed in Massachusetts, offering the clearest call yet for change as Beacon Hill grapples with how to address the billion-dollar industry.
“It’s clearly an area that has to be regulated and should be taxed,” Rosenberg told reporters today, saying he views online fantasy sports — led by the emergence of the Boston-based DraftKings, Fan Duel and other gaming sites — as akin to horse racing where one evaluates the “potential for performance and then you’re placing a wager on it.”
“We regulate and tax horse racing and we did dog racing” before it was banned in 2010, the Amherst Democrat said. “To me, it seems to be a similar thing.”
Rosenberg said he couldn’t say definitively how the state should approach it, noting that because its conducted entirely online, it’s open to anyone internationally with a credit card and Internet access.
But he said any pursuit of taxing the industry would require legislation.
Rosenberg’s comments come after Speaker of the House Robert DeLeo said in an interview that aired Sunday on WCVB-TV that the state should get its “fair share” of revenue from online gaming and suggested there may be ways to regulate the industry.
DraftKings and Fan Duel announced last week they are barring employees from playing online fantasy sports for money after a DraftKings staffer reportedly won $350,000 on the rival site, sparking allegations of insider trading. Both companies have denied any wrongdoing.
Attorney General Maura Healey said last week that fantasy sports don’t violate any state or federal laws, but said she wanted to meet with company representatives to address issues around consumer protection.
Gov. Charlie Baker — speaking this morning following testimony on charter school legislation — said he doesn’t consider himself “to be smart enough” to address how the industry could be regulated, noting that, like DeLeo, he wants to hear more from Healey.
“I do think the consumer protection stuff is important,” Baker said. “The fact that there was somebody who made ($350,000) and worked for DraftKings and had access to information on DraftKings and did that on Fan Duel, I think is a problem.”
DraftKings and FanDuel have also been on a television ad spending spree, racking up $107 million for commercials in September alone, according to media ad tracking site ispot.tv, which reported nearly half of ad spending last month went to national NFL broadcasts airing on CBS, Fox, NBC, ESPN and the NFL Network.
